column4: Hi, I've got a scsi mo drive on ubuntu, anybody knows which device this would be in /dev to be used for mounting?
it depends on whether you have any other scsi, sata or usb mass storage devices. If not, it will be /dev/sda. Try 'cat /proc/scsi/scsi' to get an idea of what's connected
two devices, one cdrom , one mo drive
is there a medium in the drive?

two things: you could do a 'dmesg | less' and search for a substring of the line in /proc/scsi/scsi that corresponds to your drive, and you could run 'tail -f /var/log/syslog' to see if any errors are logged while you insert an MO disk.
no errors visible. dmesg shows the MO drive at target 0:0:4, syslog looks fine (some gconfd errors). BTW, this is not the most recent ubuntu, this one has kernel 2.6.12-10-386
how are you checking for the device?
kernel age shouldn't matter in this case
what do you mean with 'checking for the device'? I found the device in /proc/scsi/scsi and the kernel log
it's strange, you should have /dev/sd? devices
no, none at all, neither /dev/sd* nor /dev/sg*. The cdrom (in fstab) is listed at /dev/scd0

I'm not sure what would be best to do -- you could do some surgery like creating devices with mknod or rerunning MAKEDEV. I'd first boot a live CD though to see if the drive gets a /dev/sd? device there.
thanks. I'll go for the makedev first, since my bios doesn't seem to like the mixture of scsi and ide drives for booting from cdrom.
I can definitely say that I've used MO media in a SCSI drive that were mounted via the /dev/sda1 special file.
thanks! makedev sda worked fine! Just wondering why it wasn't there before
